b. ?Grand soin d’ellej luij semble avoir été pris t.
c. ?Grand soin de Mariej luik semble avoir été pris t.
d. *Grand soin de Mariej luij semble avoir été pris t.
‘Good care of Mary/her seemed to me/her to have been taken.’

(90)
a. ?Le parti de Marie me semble avoir été pris t trois fois.
b. ?Sonj parti luij semble avoir été pris t trois fois.
c. ?Le parti de Mariej luik semble avoir été pris t trois fois.
d. *Le parti de Mariej luij semble avoir été pris t trois fois.
‘Mary's/her side seemed to me/her to have been taken three times.’

To get a Condition C effect, the name must be c-commanded by the pronoun either in underlying structure or at LF. If the former, a reason must be found as to why an NP object of an idiom chunk must be inserted in underlying structure. If the latter, we must suppose that we reconstruct into the trace position material that was never there in the first place. (What then is the reconstruction process?)

Similar conclusions can be reached by looking at cases (cf. Sportiche 1997, 1999; Romero 1997a; Fox 1999) in which a raised subject containing a name is understood as under the scope of the raising verb. Fox (1999), provides the following example, again going in the same direction:
(91) *For these issues to be clarified, many more new papers about Quinej's philosophy seem to himj [t to be needed].

Fox's reported judgment is as indicated. This sentence is constructed so as to strongly favor a reading in which the existence of these new papers is not asserted. In other words, it strongly favors a reading in which the subject is interpreted as reconstructed in the scope of the verb seem, i.e., as corresponding to the underlying representation in (92):
(92) seem to himj [to be needed many more new papers about Quinej's philosophy]
Its status ensues from the Condition C violation that is incurred.
As a control, note that coreference per se is not problematic. (93), with the pronoun and the name swapped, is fine:
(93) Many more new papers about his philosophy seem to Quinej [t to be needed].
All these are cases in which movement removes an offending configuration for Condition C, and thus they argue against the idea that Condition C is an Anywhere Principle.

We conclude that Condition C applies at LF and does not apply to underlying structures. 19 This is not compatible with P4, but it is with P5 and thus favors the latter (under either construal: cyclic or last cyclic). It is less clear at this point whether P5 is correct in stating that Condition C only applies at LF rather than, say, to surface representations as well (if they are different). In a Minimalist model such as Chomsky's (1995c), given the results above, LF would indeed be the only option.

Assuming the correctness of P5 raises further problems. If the mapping from (what roughly corresponds to) surface representations to LF is not trivial, it remains to be explained why, in general, such mapping operations (wh-in-situ interpretation, quantifier raising – apart perhaps from the ACD cases discussed earlier) never bleed Condition C. For example:

(94)
a. A different person compared her to every picture of Jane.
b. Who told him about which picture of Bill?

In (94a), every picture of Jane can outscope a different person, but this interpretive operation (quantifier raising to a position higher than the subject) cannot remove the Condition C violation incurred if her and Jane are coreferential. In (94b), if wh-movement preposes which picture of Bill to [spec, CP], there will not be a Condition C violation at LF.

One option is to assume that there are no ‘covert’ operations (cf. Williams 1986; Brody 1995b); another is to assume that Condition C applies to ‘surface-like’ structures. In Chomsky's (1995c) Minimalist framework, the second option is unavailable and the first is not considered. This is why, talking about wh-in situ interpretation, Chomsky suggests that such mapping operations move only the quantifier and not the whole DP (just the D without the NP), here yielding (95), which still violates Condition C:
(95) which [who told him about t picture of Bill]

Chomsky's copy theory of traces could be construed differently to handle this general observation. Adopting for expository purposes Fox's (2002) construal of such copies as definite descriptions and assuming phrasal covert movement, the LF of (94a) would roughly be (96):
(96) for every picture of Jane [a different person compared her to this picture of Jane]

New problems of course now arise: if traces are copies, or if movement is limited to Ds, what happens in the cases of ACD discussed above? We refer to Fox (1999, 2002) and Fox and Nissenbaum (1999) for further discussion.

subsection.heading: 4.2.3 Predicate–argument asymmetry
subsection.p: Unlike argument preposing, predicate preposing does not seem to increase the set of possible antecedents for a pied-pied anaphor. This contrast is illustrated in (97):

(97)
a. They think that [these pictures of each other], John likes t.
b. *They think that [visit each other's parents], John will t.
How should this contrast be handled?

One class of proposals (Williams 1980; Barss 1986, 1988; Huang 1993; and in part Reinhart and Reuland 1993) require (using different devices) that nothing other than the subject of a predicate can bind an anaphor inside this predicate from outside this predicate: either the anaphor is bound internally to the predicate phrase, or it is bound by the subject of this predicate. Clearly all such proposals will be able to exclude (97b), since the only antecedent it would allow for the reciprocal would be John. However, most will be insufficient in general to extend to cases not involving anaphors. For example, Barss (1986) and Heycock (1995) note the ill-formedness of the type of example in (98):

(98)
a. *[Bribe a Nobel Prize winner]k, he did tk.
b. *[Bribe a Nobel Prize winner]k, he says youj did tk.

The relevant factor here is that coreference between he and a Nobel Prize winner is excluded. One option for handling these facts would be to adopt Lebeaux's (1991) proposal that Condition C is an Anywhere Principle and cannot be violated at any stage of the derivation. However, we have seen that this option is not tenable. Furthermore, it would not generalize to the anaphor cases.

In effect what is needed to handle all of these cases ((97) and (98)) is some reason why reconstruction of preposed predicates to their lowest trace is required. If such is the case, examples (97b) and (98b) would respectively receive the LFs in (99):

(99)
a. *They think that [visit each other's parents], John will [visit each other's parents].
b. *[Bribe a Nobel Prize Winner], he says you did.
whose ill-formed status follows immediately. This is exactly what Barss (1986) proposes. The question is now why it should be true that reconstruction of predicates is required.

There are two proposals in the literature. The first is an elaboration of Huang (1993) due to Takano (1995), which we will detail below. The second is due to Heycock (1995), who argues that predicates must always reconstruct for scope reasons. If we accept that predicates must (at least under normal circumstances) take narrow scope – and Heycock (1995) provides strong supporting evidence for this claim – we derive the reconstruction properties of preposed predicates. We only have an explanation, however, if we can derive the idea that predicates must have narrow scope. Otherwise, we simply have a sophisticated stipulation of the result that we want with as many stipulated properties (= predicates must have narrow scope) as results (= they must reconstruct). In other words, granting that predicates must always reconstruct for scope reasons, the question is why.

If the semantic properties of predicates somehow precluded them from being interpreted with wide scope, we would have such an explanation, but there do not seem to be reasons why failure to reconstruct a predicate should lead to semantic ill-formedness. Thus a priori there is nothing wrong with representation of the meaning of (100a) as (100b) with wide scope of the predicate:

(100)
a. John will sleep.
b. There is a property P of sleeping, will (P (John)). (assuming verbs range over properties or relations)

Huang's (1993) proposal seems to be successfully extendable to all such cases, and with some explanatory power, because it seems independently plausible given general assumptions about phrase structure. Regarding anaphors, Huang suggests the preposing of predicates actually always preposes a constituent containing the subject of this predicate. As a result, the domain within which the anaphor must be bound is no larger than this preposed constituent itself.

The details of this proposal are as follows: first, the subject of a predicate is always generated internally to the projection of this predicate as specifier of this projection (this is the so-called Predicate Internal Subject Hypothesis, justified on independent grounds). In underlying structure, the subject of a verb V (or an adjective A) is always the specifier of the corresponding VP (or AP). If this subject shows up elsewhere, it has been moved. For example, (101a) has the surface structure indicated in (101b):

(101)
a. John will see Mary.
b. Johnj will [VP tj [see Mary]].
The structure of the example involving VP-preposing now looks as in (102):

(102)
a. Visit each other's friends, you think they said [Bill and Mary]j will tk.
b. [tj Visit each other's friends]k, you think they said [Bill and Mary]j will tk.

The trace tj closes off the domain within which each other can look for an antecedent and thus can be the only antecedent available. Since this trace is the trace of Bill and Mary, Bill and Mary is the only allowed antecedent. One appealing aspect of this proposal is that under these assumptions about phrase structure, pied-piping of the subject trace follows from the general properties of phrasal movement: the subject trace is within the minimal phrasal constituent containing the predicate and thus must move along with it; the minimal movable projection of a predicate always contains the (trace of the) subject of this predicate.
Of course, this proposal covers (98a) but not (98b), repeated – with traces – as (103):

(103)
a. *[tj Bribe a Nobel Prize winner]k, hej did tk.
b. *[tj Bribe a Nobel Prize winner]k, hem says youj did tk.

As we saw earlier, (98b) would also be straightforwardly handled as a Condition C effect if the VP were forced to literally reconstruct: the description a Nobel Prize winner would be c-commanded by the coreferential pronoun he, thus triggering a Condition C effect.

If we modify Huang's proposal and suppose that literal reconstruction of moved predicates is required we handle all the relevant facts. This is Takano's (1995) proposal. The Huang–Takano proposal provides a simple reason why literal reconstruction is required: traces are bound variables and must, at LF, be in the scope of (i.e., be c-commanded by) their binders. 20 In particular, if a preposed predicate does not reconstruct, it will leave the trace of the subject that it contains without c-commanding antecedent. Thus the behavior of fronted predicates is ultimately due to the Predicate Internal Subject Hypothesis (as Huang suggested), but in two different ways: for anaphors because the predicate always has a trace subject, and for Condition C because this trace forces reconstruction of the fronted predicate.

Heycock (1995) argues not only that the Huang–Takano proposal is insufficient, 21 but also that it is too strong. We will comment on Heycock's arguments and their inconclusiveness in sections 5.3.2 and 5.3.3.

subsection.heading: 4.3 Scope
subsection.p: We now turn to a more systematic investigation of the interaction of reconstruction for binding and reconstruction for scope. As we will see, such considerations play a major role in determining reconstruction possibilities (as shown, for example, in Cresti 1995; Heycock 1995; Fox 1999), and lead to substantial reformulations of the problem. In this subsection, we discuss scope reconstruction. In the next section we will turn to the interaction of scope and binding reconstruction.

We have already seen all sorts of reconstruction effect for scope, e.g., cases of pronominal binding, reciprocal binding, and quantifier–predicate interactions. We now focus a bit more on the last of these. Recall that in such sentences as (15) (repeated here as (104)), in which we paraphrase compose as cause to be in existence and perform as cause to be performed:

(104)
a. How many songs will you compose?
b. How many songs will you perform?
we can paraphrase (104a) by (16a) (repeated here as (105a)), and (104b) by either (16b) or (16c) (repeated here as (105b, c)):

(105)
a. For what number x, you will cause there to be x many songs in existence?
b. For what number x, you will cause there to be x many songs performed?
c. For what number x, there are x many songs you will cause to be performed?
= How many songs are there that you will perform?

As outlined above, the difference lies in the scope of the existential quantification rendered here by there are . . . with respect to the expression will cause. Reading (105c) is less natural in the case of (104a): we cannot assert the existence of a set of objects with certain properties if these objects do not yet exist (presuming that if the songs are not composed yet, they do not exist). 22 We have called the readings in (105) and (105b) the narrow-scope or narrow readings (since there has narrower scope than will cause) and the reading in (105c) the wide-scope or wide reading.

As has often been noted (see, e.g., Dobrovie-Sorin 1994b; Heycock 1995), we can unambiguously render the narrow readings of (104a, b) in French as in (106a, b). 23 The wide reading of (104b) is rendered by (106c), which also allows the narrow reading:

(106)
a. Combien vas-tu composer de chansons?
how many will you compose of songs
b. Combien vas-tu chanter de chansons?
how many will you sing of songs
c. Combien de chansons vas-tu chanter?
how many songs will you sing

Call the construction exemplified in the first two sentences combien-split. Given that combien means ‘what is the number (or quantity) x such that’, it is natural to take the position of de chansons to correspond to the locus of the existential quantification ‘there are x many songs’. In this way, the surface form of the French narrow-reading question seems to be exactly what we need to express its meaning, as (106a) essentially has the form of (105a). By the same token, (106c) has the form of (105c). It is thus plausible to assume that the ambiguity of the English sentence (104b) is represented at LF by varying what reconstructs:

(107)
a. Reconstruction: how many will you perform songs (narrow reading)
No reconstruction: how many songs will you perform (wide reading)
This plausibility argument as to what the LF representations of such sentences are finds support from some French facts noted in De Swart (1998): 24

(108)
a. Combien de chansons les enfants ont-ils tous chanté(s)?
how many of songs the children have-they all sung
b. Combien les enfants ont-ils tous chanté de chansons?
how many the children have-they all sung of songs
c. For what number x, the children all caused there to be x many songs performed?
d. For what number x, there are x many songs the children all caused to be performed?

The sentence in (108b) has only a narrow reading, represented by (108c), with the existential quantifier (there) in the scope of the universal quantifier (all) so that the choice of the songs to be performed can vary with each child. Given that floated quantifiers always take their surface scope, this reading is predicted by the assumed LF representation for narrow readings. The sentence in (108a) is ambiguous between the narrow and the wide reading. Under the wide reading, represented by (108d), the existential quantifier (there) is not in the scope of the universal quantifier (all) so that the choice of the songs cannot vary with each child. To make this more concrete, imagine an exam situation in which children have to sing six songs. Three of them are the exact same three for all the children (the imposed program), and the other three are freely chosen by each child (the free program). To (108a), it is possible to truthfully answer ‘three’ or ‘six’. To (108c), only ‘six’ is a truthful answer.

subsection.heading: 5 Simultaneous reconstruction requirements
subsection.p: In this section, we discuss what happens in situations in which the requirements of several binding and/or scope principles must be simultaneously satisfied. We actually already have encountered such situations, but we now discuss them somewhat more systematically. A coherent overall theory of reconstruction should be able to handle all such cases – certainly a non-trivial task and, if achieved, a non-trivial result.

We begin by discussing interactions between Condition C and pronominal binding. Next we turn to quantifier–predicate scope and Condition C. Finally, we examine the case of predicate preposing and its interaction with scope considerations and Condition C.

subsection.heading: 5.1 Condition C, Condition A, and pronominal binding
subsection.p: Lebeaux (1991) reports that Condition C effects and the possibilities for pronominal binding correlate. He discusses examples similar to (109) (from Fox 1999, in which more such examples are discussed):

(109)
a. *Which survey that he could show to the typical female viewer would she hope no pollster would publish t?
b. Which survey that he could show to her would the typical female viewer hope no pollster would publish t?
c. (Desired answer to both: ‘His most embarrassing.’)
*Quel sondage qu’il pourrait montrer à Madame toutlemonde ne laisserait-t-elle aucun journaliste publier t?
d. Quel sondage qu’il pourrait lui montrer Madame toutlemonde ne laisserait-t-elle aucun journaliste publier t?

In order for the pronoun he to be understood as bound by the quantifier no pollster, reconstruction of the relative clause must take place. However, if reconstruction takes place, this puts the indirect object of the verb show in the c-command domain of the subject of the verb hope. If the latter is a pronoun, and the former is a name or a description, we should observe a Condition C effect, and we do, as in (109a). Otherwise we should not, as in (109b). The deviance of (109a) indicates that Condition C and the condition on pronominal binding cannot be checked on strictly different inputs. If they were, we should be able to satisfy Condition C on some input and the condition on pronominal Binding on another at which the Condition C configuration is not met. This, for example, would be the case if Condition C applied at S-structure but not at LF and pronominal binding were checked at LF but not at S-structure. 25 This reinforces the idea that Condition C applies at LF (but says nothing about whether or not, in addition, Condition C applies elsewhere, e.g., to surface representations).

The same point can be illustrated with reciprocals, which also act as variables bound by their antecedents. This also illustrates an interaction between the locality requirement of Condition A and Condition C. Contrast (110a, b):

(110)
a. *Which stories about each other's characterizations of the typical male viewer would he conclude the journalists should publish?
b. Which stories about each other's characterizations of him would the typical male viewer conclude the journalists should publish?

(110a) does not seem to allow the reading in (111a), but (110b) allows the reading in (111b). Some care is needed to evaluate this contrast, as we want to make sure that the interpretation under which (110a) and (110b) are judged has the relevant distributive readings, which can (roughly) be paraphrased as (111a, b): 26

(111)
a. Which stories about the others’ characterizations of the typical male viewer would he conclude each journalist should publish?
b. Which stories about the others’ characterizations of him would the typical male viewer conclude each journalist should publish?

subsection.heading: 5.2 Scope and Condition C
subsection.p: The conclusion that the LF of the narrow and wide readings is as in (107) directly bears on the relationship between scope and binding with respect to reconstruction, as extensively discussed in Heycock (1995). She reports the contrasts (the examples are slightly changed) in (112a, b) which we will discuss in turn. For the first one, imagine the following context in which no prior virtual existence has been established for such surveys (cf. note 23): have the opinions of the typical male viewer been taken into account in designing surveys of his TV viewing habits? Should we send questionnaires out to him to help us formulate the questions? Is it worth it, given the low response rate we get? In the end, when all is counted:

(112)
a. *How many surveys about the typical male viewer is he likely to help design t?
b. How many surveys about the typical male viewer is he likely to challenge t?
c. *How many is he likely to help design surveys about the typical male viewer?
d. How many surveys about the typical male viewer is he likely to challenge t?
Let us examine these sentences in turn.

subsection.heading: 5.2.1 The wide-scope reading
subsection.p: Let us first consider the meaning of (112b), repeated here. Here, we can easily imagine a context in which the surveys about the typical male viewer already exist, since he is likely to challenge them. This makes the wide reading readily available, which means that the LF (112d) (repeated here) is fine, avoiding a Condition C effect:

(112)
b. How many surveys about the typical male viewer is he likely to challenge t?
d. How many surveys about the typical male viewer is he likely to challenge t?

We are now faced with an apparent contradiction. We had concluded that reconstruction of non-adjunct pied-piped material is obligatory to guarantee that we observe Condition C effects. This means that at least the nominal surveys should reconstruct. For scopal reasons, however, it looks as though we want the same nominal not to reconstruct.
This problem becomes more acute in (113):

(113)
a. *How many pictures of a famous artist you know is he looking for t?
b. LF1: How many pictures of a famous artist you know is he looking for?
c. LF2: How many is he looking for pictures of a famous artist you know?

Clearly the sentence in (113a) can receive a wide reading and thus get the LF representation LF1 in (113b). This predicts that under the wide reading there should not be any Condition C effect. But this seems wrong: coreference between the underlined elements is blocked in (113a). To get this result, we would need to postulate instead of LF1 the logical form LF2, given in (113c). But this would wrongly claim that only the narrow reading is available for (113a).

A solution to this problem can be constructed by using Chomsky's (1995c) theory of movement traces as copies, which we have already seen helps resolve other problems. 27 According to Chomsky's proposal, a sentence like (114a) would have (114b) as surface syntactic representation, (114c) as input to phonology (Phonetic Form or PF), and (114d) as manipulated surface structure for the purpose of interpretation (LF):

(114)
a. How many books are you looking for?
b. Surface Form: How many books are you looking for how many books?
c. What PF sees: How many books are you looking for how many books?
d. What LF sees: How many books are you looking for how many books?

Chomsky's copy theory of movement has several positive aspects. First, it eliminates the need to postulate objects (traces), whose internal structure is not entirely clear (e.g., how do traces obey X-bar theory?). Second, Move is an operation of copying a moving phrase and deleting the original copy. The copy theory turns movement into a simpler operation, essentially identical to the elementary structure-building operation (merge). It differs only in taking as input an object that has served as input for an earlier merger – move is merge-the-same-object-again, that is, by appealing to a notion of identity of distinct syntactic objects which seem independently required by cases of ellipsis, as Chomsky (1995c) notes. The ‘deletion’ part is now handled independently as part of PF interpretation or LF interpretation, and there can be mismatches between what is deleted in PF and what is deleted in LF, as the paradigm in (114) makes clear. 28

Turning back to the problem raised by (113a), we can resolve the contradiction by departing from Chomsky's proposal and assume that the LF of (113a) is not (113c) but rather a representation in which both the moved copy and the original copy are interpreted at LF. 29 In the case of a narrow reading, reconstruction must be obligatory, as we have now seen several times. In the case of the wide reading, it is important that the moved constituent be interpreted with wide scope, but nothing prevents a copy of this constituent from being interpreted in the original trace position as well. This permits a reconciliation of scope considerations with the obligatory character of reconstruction of pied-piped complements necessary to explain certain Condition C effects. 30

The idea that both copies can be interpreted is developed in Fox (1999) for different reasons (see also Brody 1995b; Safir 1999; Rizzi 2000a). Fox suggests that the ‘bottom’ trace is interpreted like a definite description. Other possibilities could be contemplated (Safir 1999 treats it like a pronoun), but from now on, for ease of exposition, we will represent the lower copy as a demonstrative expression referring back to the top copy when there are two (or more) copies. For the sentence in (115a), this would yield the LF representations (115b) for the narrow reading and (115c) for the wide reading. Taking Fox's proposal into account, we will understand the LF of (115c) as (115d):

(115)
a. The sentence: How many pictures of a famous artist is he looking for t?
b. Its narrow-reading LF: How many is he looking for pictures of a famous artist?
c. Its wide-reading LF: How many pictures of a famous artist is he looking for pictures of a famous artist?
d. Paraphrase of the wide-reading LF: How many pictures of a famous artist are such that he looking for these pictures of a famous artist?
The effect of interpreting both copies in the case of wide readings are clear: in all cases, we see that coreference between he and a famous artist leads to a Condition C violation.

subsection.heading: 5.2.2 The narrow-scope reading
subsection.p: Turning now to (112a), its reported deviance might look surprising. Since about the typical male viewer is an adjunct, it should be allowed not to reconstruct and thus should not have to feed Condition C. The reason for the deviance, Heycock (1995) hypothesizes for similar examples, is that the LF representation of (112a) must be (112c), with reconstruction of the restriction of how many. Indeed, the surveys about the typical male viewer not having been designed yet, only the narrow reading of this question is plausible. In (112b), the wide reading is plausible, thus allowing the LF (112d), which causes no Condition C violation.

Note that in such circumstances, for this reasoning to go through in the case of the narrow reading, it must not be possible to totally reconstruct the nominal head surveys of the preposed constituent without reconstructing the adjunct modifier about the typical male viewer as well. This seems reasonable: the adjunct must, by hypothesis, be predicated of some modifiee, to which it must stand in a syntactically local relation: as a result, it cannot be left stranded in a high position.

subsection.heading: 5.3 Predicate movement, scope, Condition C, and predicate-internal subjects
5.3.1 Scope reconstruction and islands
subsection.p: Recall that we concluded that moved predicate phrases always reconstruct. This means that predicate movement should never obviate Condition C effects or increase the set of possible antecedents for a pied-piped anaphor. These two points are again illustrated in (116):

(116)
a. *[tj Pleased with an old painter], I think he was t.
b. *[tj Pleased with an old painter], he thinks you were t.
c. *[tj Visit [each other]k 's parents], you think they said [Bill and Mary]j will t.

In (116a, b), obligatory reconstruction will put the preposed constituent back into position t, thus triggering Condition C effects. In (116c), the presence of tj prevents anything other than Bill and Mary from qualifying as antecedent for each other. Note that the Predicate Internal Subject Hypothesis truly derives the required reconstruction from the independent existence of a condition on pronominal and variable binding.

Heycock (1995) provides support for her observation that predicates are limited to taking narrow scope. This support is based on some extraction facts out of wh-islands. Several authors (e.g., Cinque 1990c, who attributes the observation to Giuseppe Longobardi) have noted that an amount question (how much, how many) out of wh-islands is only possible if this question receives a wide-scope reading in the sense of the text. Thus we find the facts in (117) (e.g., with how many):

(117)
a. *How many songs do you wonder whether Sue will compose t?
b. ?How many songs do you wonder whether Sue will perform t?

In (117a) (without context), lexical choices strongly favor the narrow reading (the wide reading, how many songs are there such that . . . , is implausible given that the songs are not yet composed). In (117b), the wide reading is plausible and the sentence is better (with the reading how many songs are there such that . . . ). 31 (See chapter 64.)
Degree questions (e.g., with how + adjective) behave like narrow-reading amount questions (as noted in Rizzi 1990b, citing Roberts 1988b and Baltin 1992) and unlike wide-reading amount questions:

(118)
a. *How intelligent did she wonder whether she was?
b. *How afraid of dogs did they ask if he was?

Heycock takes this to suggest that the only (or the only accessible) interpretation degree questions tolerate is the narrow reading; that is, that predicates must reconstruct. (If the wide reading were available, (118a, b) should have the status of (117b) and not of (117a).)

Heycock further argues (following Kroch 1989a) that the unavailability of the narrow reading in amount or degree questions out of wh-islands is due to pragmatic infelicity rather than semantic deviance or ungrammaticality. Questions out of wh-islands, they argue, require that the questioned phrase ask the identity of an entity or entities presupposed to exist. 32 In the case of the wide-reading question (117b), repeated here as (119a), the presupposition would be what is given in (119b):

(119)
a. ?How many songs do you wonder whether Sue will perform t?
b. There are songs such that you wonder whether Sue will perform them.

This should make it possible to rescue narrow readings for amount and degree questions out of wh-islands. First, Heycock (following Kroch) argues that contexts can be constructed that make amount questions or degree questions out of wh-islands more acceptable. Heycock's example is (120a), with its interpretation in (120b) and it presupposition in (120c):

(120)
a. How many points are the judges arguing about whether to deduct?
b. What is the number such that the judges are arguing about whether to deduct this number of points?
c. There is a certain number of points that the judges are arguing about whether to deduct.

Similar facts can be found in French. Normally, combien-split is sensitive to weak islands such as wh-islands or an intervening negation. In French, this is easier to check, since we can guarantee the narrow reading by using combien-split. This type of context indeed makes the approximate translation of (120a) yield the relatively acceptable (121):
(121) Combien est-ce que les juges se demandent s’il faut déduire de points?
We find similar contrasts for negative islands. (122) is hard to interpret:
(122) *Combien est ce que Jean n’a pas emprunté de livres cette année?
‘How many hasn't John borrowed books this year?’

Out of context, there is no particular presupposition about there being a number of books that one should borrow. However, this sentence improves greatly if we utter it with the presupposition that there is a certain number of books that John has not borrowed this year.

Consider now (123), asked in a context (familiar to French people) in which there is a small, fixed number of competitive exams to take every year, and every student decides which ones to take and which ones to opt out of. It is then perfectly natural to ask how many competitive exams John decided to opt out of, as in (123a) (with the intended interpretation in (123b)):

(123)
a. Combien est ce que Jean n’a pas passé de concours cette année? 33
‘How many hasn't John taken of competitive exams this year?’
b. What is the number/it is not the case that John took this number of exams this year.

Extraction out of wh-islands of degree-modified predicates can also easily be done. For example, in the following context, sentence (124a) is fine: ‘According to reliable sources, Einstein's sister was just as well informed and just as smart as him and he was extremely proud of her.’ Just as well informed, I can believe’ but:

(124)
a. This smart, I wonder whether she was t.
b. *This proud of Einstein's sister, I wonder whether he was t.
c. This proud of his sister, I wonder whether every student ever was t.

We must make sure that sentence (124a) is not a case of wide reading but rather a case of felicitous narrow reading, since predicates must always reconstruct, ruling out wide readings in degree questions in principle. First, note that (124b) is still deviant. This shows that a copy of the predicate phrase is interpreted as reconstructed, but does not exclude the presence of an interpreted copy at the top as well. The well-formedness of the third sentence (in an appropriate context) does show that such structures may be interpreted with no copy left at the top (otherwise we would have an unbound pronoun). This does not demonstrate that wide readings are unavailable for preposed predicates, but at least it shows that such examples as (124a) can be treated as cases of narrow readings, i.e., as having the interpretation in (125):
(125) There is an amount X such that, I wonder whether she was X smart.

subsection.heading: 5.3.2 Definite descriptions, predicate-internal subjects, and partial reconstruction
subsection.p: Heycock also discusses the contrasts in (126):

(126)
a. *[How afraid of some question Gore has not prepared for] do you think he is now?
b. [How pleased with the pictures Pollock painted long ago] do you think he is now t?

The unacceptability of (126a) is predicted. Forced reconstruction of the preposed predicate phrase puts Gore in the c-command domain of he, thus triggering a Condition C effect. The acceptability of (126b) is unexpected. To deal with this, Heycock suggests that the definite description the pictures that Pollock painted long ago can be assigned wide scope, deriving the representation in (127):
(127) [The pictures that Pollock painted long ago]k, how do you think he was pleased with tk?

Heycock remarks that if this wide-scope reading becomes less plausible, a Condition C effect reappears. This is the case in (126a), in which it is most natural for the relative clause not to be interpreted with widest scope. The contrast in (128a, b) is similar:

(128)
a. How jealous of a girl that Mary had met at the party did she become?
b. *How eager for a friend that Mary might confide in would she become?

It is possible to interpret the underlined indefinite in (128a) as having wide scope (‘There is a girl that Mary had met at the party: how jealous of her did she become?’). Such a wide-scope reading for the indefinite is far less plausible for (128b).
Let us examine how this proposal can be reconciled with earlier conclusions. Consider again (126b), repeated here as (129):
(129) [How pleased with the pictures Pollock painted long ago] do you think he is now?

We must obligatorily reconstruct the predicate and its complement, and scope out the definite description in such a way that it leaves no interpreted copy below the pronoun he. In this instance, this is possible because we need not reconstruct adjuncts, and an adjunct contains the potentially offending name. This yields (130):
(130) [How the pictures Pollock painted long ago do you think he is pleased with these pictures] now?
in which the lower copy does not contain the relative clause.
That this is on the right track seems supported by the contrast between (131a) and (131b):

(131)
a. [How pleased with the pictures an old painter you know painted long ago] do you think he is?
b. *[How pleased with the pictures of an old painter you know] do you think he is?

The difference between them is that the potentially offending name is contained in an adjunct in (131a), and can thus fail to reconstruct. In (131b), it is part of the complement structure and thus must be reconstructed, triggering a Condition C effect.
Similarly, it is clear why (132) is a Condition C violation, given the only possible LF representation it could have:

(132)
a.
I gave him this picture of Bill yesterday.
b. LF: [This picture of Bill]j, I gave him this picture of Bill yesterday.

However, the lack of obviation of Condition C effects in sentences such as in (133) is problematic. They would get the corresponding representations in (134) after scoping out of the definite description (leaving only copies of non-adjunct material), and would thus be predicted to escape Condition C, contrary to fact:

(133)
a. *He says that the man who an old painter met left.
b. *She considers the book a European princess wrote to be unreadable.
c. *I told him that the man who an old painter met left.
d. *Hej wonders [how pleased with the pictures an old painter you know painted long ago] you are.

(134)
a. The man who an old painter met [he says that this man left].
b. The book a European princess wrote [she considers this book to be unreadable].
c. The man who an old painter met [I told him that this man left].
d. [The pictures an old painter you know painted long ago] hej wonders [how pleased with these pictures] you are.

One way out could be to restrict the distance that the definite description can scope over. If, roughly, it were clause bound, all these problems would disappear. This would predict, however, that (135a) should still be fine (viz. its representation in (135b) after scoping out of the definite description):

(135)
a. Je lui ai donné la photo que le vieux peintre m’a demandée.
b. I gave him the picture the old painter asked for yesterday.
c. [The picture an old painter asked for], I gave him this picture.

The French sentence in (135a) given in English in (135b), is clearly much better than (132a) and indeed is perfectly fine, particularly if read with such an intonation that the (underlined) direct object is backgrounded. This, however, may be an effect due to ‘extraposition’ of the relative clause.
The examples in (136) are sharply out:

(136)
a. *Il m’a donné la photo que le vieux peintre m’a demandée.
b. *He gave me the picture the old painter asked for yesterday.
c. [The picture the old painter asked for], he gave me this picture.
d. He [the picture the old painter asked for] gave me this picture.

This suggests that if descriptions can scope out within their clause, leaving a copy optionally containing adjunct material, the distance this movement can span is quite restricted. Here the definite description must stay lower than a definite subject. Note that in the initial case in (130), scoping of the definite description is from within a preposed wh-phrase. Clearly this is an area for further research.

subsection.heading: 5.3.3 What drives predicate reconstruction?
subsection.p: The structure of (126b) under Huang's (1993) proposal is (137):
(137) [How tj pleased with the pictures Pollockj painted long ago] do you think hej is now t?

This would seem incompatible with Huang's proposal, Heycock (1995) claims. The presence of tj coindexed with he should trigger a Condition C effect (whether Condition C is an Anywhere Principle or only applies at LF). Under a theory assuming that Condition C cannot be violated anywhere, such examples are clearly incompatible with Huang's proposal, since at some level, tj c-commands an old painter. But this problem is more general: this sentence poses a problem for any account assuming that the preposed predicate obligatorily reconstructs in its entirety to t, putting Pollock in the c-command domain of he. To get around this problem, Heycock suggests that definite descriptions can scope out. If Heycock's proposal is on the right track and the LF representation of (137) is (138):
(138) The pictures Pollock painted long ago [how do you think hej is tj pleased with these pictures]?

the problem Heycock points out for Huang's proposal is also solved by her proposal under the assumption that Condition C only applies at LF: once the definite description has been scoped out and the adjunct is not reconstructed, there is no longer a Condition C violation, regardless of the presence of a predicate-internal subject. We conclude that the Huang–Takano proposal (see section 4.2.3) can be maintained.
In Heycock (1995), one additional problem is mentioned regarding Takano's modification of Huang's proposal that we have been discussing. The examples of degree questions in (139) allow coreference:

(139)
a. How much longer than your yacht actually is did John think it was?
b. How much more intelligent than John actually is did he say he was?

Of course, this would be a problem if Condition C were an Anywhere Principle. Is it so under the assumption that Condition C applies only at LF? To decide whether this indeed constitutes a problem, we must examine what the LFs of (139) can be. In (139b), for example, the than clause is a dependent of more. (In its absence, the than clause could not be present). Thus, the representation in (140) of this amount question seems reasonable:
(140) What is the degree D added to the degree to which John is actually intelligent such that he said he was D intelligent?

This makes it basically a narrow-reading amount question on a degree, in which no LF violation of Condition C should occur (the wh-question bears on a degree increase, but the predicate intelligent has narrow scope). As Heycock remarks, that this is a narrow-reading amount question is corroborated by the fact that such questions become unacceptable when originating inside a wh-island: 34,35
(141) *How much more intelligent than he is do you wonder whether he was?

subsection.heading: 6 Conclusion
subsection.p: We begin with a summary of the conclusions we reached first descriptively. Then we summarize the accounts that these descriptive generalizations seem to suggest in a Principles and Parameters type of model.
Descriptively, we concluded that:

li.p: We find reconstruction effects for scope, pronominal binding, and all binding conditions in all types of movement constructions.
Reconstruction for preposed predicates is always required, with consequences for all relevant conditions: Condition A, Condition C, scope, and pronominal binding.

Regarding Condition C, reconstruction is obligatory sometimes and optional at other times. We took the relevant factor to be a complement–adjunct distinction, but it is not fully established that this is the relevant distinction.
Reconstruction for Condition A, scope, and pronominal binding is possible but not required.
Reconstruction effects correlate to a certain extent: reconstruction for pronominal binding and scope either both take place or both do not.

If reconstruction for scope or pronominal binding takes place, reconstruction for Condition C does too. (This is only relevant for cases of optional reconstruction for Condition C; that is, it only relates to adjuncts.)
Reconstruction effects, however, do not always correlate: reconstruction may take place for Condition C without doing so for scope.
There were cases of impossible reconstruction, which we left unexplained.

subsection.p: We construed these descriptive generalizations as follows:

li.p: All binding conditions and scope computation must be computed on the basis of representations that serve as input for semantic interpretation, which we define as LF. It makes little sense for scope or pronominal binding (in effect a scope principle) to be evaluated anywhere else (at best it would be redundant). We reached similar conclusions for Condition A, although it should be noted that we did not discuss potentially relevant differences between reflexives and reciprocals.

Condition C cannot hold of underlying structures but may of surface structures (depending on the treatment of antecedent-contained deletion and the correctness of the Huang–Takano approach, among other things).
Mismatch of scope and binding reconstruction patterns can be handled by taking traces to be copies and requiring that bottom (or bottom-most) copies always be interpreted at LF.

The obligatoriness of reconstruction for preposed predicates can be tentatively attributed to the Huang–Takano hypothesis, and to the idea that interpreted traces (which are lower copies) behave as bound variables (and are thus subject to the condition on pronominal binding).

subsection.p: It is worth noting that these conclusions are consistent with Chomsky's (1995c) proposal requiring all binding conditions to be LF conditions only.
Regarding the properties of movement, we reached the following conclusion regarding how to construe the basic operation Move and its interaction with LF principles of scope:

li.p: Either or both copies can be interpreted at LF.
The position determining the scope of an XP is that of its highest interpreted copy.
If only the lower copy of an XP is interpreted, this XP receives narrow scope.
If the top copy of an XP is interpreted, this XP receives wide scope.

subsection.p: Among the issues left unresolved are the existence and exact properties of covert movement (although we have been led to the assumption that covert scoping out is possible, e.g., for definite descriptions), the impact of the analysis of relative clauses on the theory of reconstruction, and the behavior of reflexives.

Descriptively, there are a number of questions we have not discussed. We have not talked about reconstruction effects for negative- or positive-polarity-item licensing (see Den Dikken et al. 2000 for some relevant discussion). We also have not discussed the properties of reconstruction documented in other languages (e.g., in Arabic: see Aoun and Benmamoun 1998; in British English: see Elbourne 1999; or in Japanese: see Saito 1989 on scrambling).

Theoretically, we have limited ourselves to implementing the assumed descriptive generalizations in a Principles and Parameters type of framework, but we have of course not discussed all approaches to reconstruction within it. Among recent works that were not discussed here, there are approaches assuming PF movement (e.g., Aoun and Benmamoun 1998; Sauerland and Elbourne 2002). The work of Safir (1999) incorporates ideas about vehicle change originally proposed in May and Fiengo (1994) into the treatment of reconstruction effects (by treating lower copies as pronominals, for example). Putting the burden of the treatment of reconstruction effects onto the semantic rules themselves rather than onto the syntactic input to these interpretive rules is done in flexible composition rules approaches, such as Jacobson (1999) or Sharvit (1998). More distant treatments of reconstruction effects can be found in McCawley (1999) within generative semantics. As mentioned at the outset, it remains to be seen to what extent these alternatives are truly different from what we have covered in the logical structure of the proposals that they make.

which seem paradoxical as the object of the verb of creation is definite (and thus referring to some pre-existing entity). Even examples similar to Heycock's (1995) below, carefully chosen to eliminate this possibility, can be circumvented in an appropriate context:
(iii) How many stories about John is she likely to invent?

could be uttered felicitously with a wide reading if we interpret this not as an actual present but as a historical present (reviewing the woman's life and knowing all the stories she invented, we can mentally place ourselves at some stage of her life and utter (iii) meaning ‘(Of all the stories she will invent in her life) how many of these is she likely to invent at this point)?’ In what follows, we always assume that we are not in such contexts in the narrow-scope examples.

p.span: 23 To the author's ear, only the narrow reading remains available even if we modify the sentence to allow for a pre-established set of songs in discourse, as in:

row.entry: Combien vas-tu chanter de chansons apprises l’an dernier?
how many will you sing songs learned last year

subsection.p: The construction combien . . . de differs from the (partitive) construction combien . . . des (where des = de +les), as in:
(ii) Combien vas-tu chanter des chansons apprises l’an dernier?
which also allows moving combien by itself but uses a different (extraposed) intonation and is ambiguous. See also Fox (1999: 153, fn. 20).

p.span: 24 Two remarks on these data: first, the agreement on the past participle in (108a) is indicated as optional. The correct description is more complex: it depends on the reading that is assigned to the question: (impossible with the narrow reading, optional with the wide reading). See Obenauer (1994) for relevant discussion. Second, de Swart reports the French facts differently: she reports that under the wide reading, the universal quantifier tous can take scope of the wh -word combien (so that the number varies with each child). I think such a reading – a pair-list reading – is impossible with a floated Q, but would be possible with a non-floated Q (i.e., in Combien de chansons tous les enfants ont-ils chanté? ).

25 Recall that the condition on pronominal binding cannot fail to be checked at the level at which interpretation is actually performed, i.e., LF, by definition, so the only possibility for strictly different inputs for Condition C and pronominal binding is if Condition C applies to surface or underlying structures (if they are different from LF structures).
26 In particular, parasitic readings should be avoided, e.g.:

subsection.p: (i) Stories about each other's characterizations = Each story is about the characterization of the other stories
(ii) Stories about each other's characterizations = Each one's story about the others’ characterizations

p.span: 27 This idea is already present in various form in earlier literature, e.g., Burzio (1986). Chomsky, however, uses and justifies it in ways consistent with our present discussion.

28 One problem with copy theory is that portions of the resulting interface representations (in Chomsky's 1995c sense) are allowed to be ignored. This raises questions regarding the empirical content of the ‘bare output’ (or ‘legibility’) conditions crucial to Chomsky's (1995c) minimal design conjecture.
29 This proposal takes care of all the problems raised in Heycock (1995: section 6) for the idea that Condition C applies only at LF.
30 Another option would be to get the wide reading from a representation like:

subsection.p: (i) How many you are looking for pictures?

and let the indefinite pictures take wide scope by other mechanisms (e.g., choice function). Space precludes a discussion of this option. Let us remark that it would wrongly predict impossible answers to questions such as (108a).

p.span: 31 It is not relevant here why such a difference is observed. For proposals, see chapter 64 and references therein.
32 There are other proposals similar in spirit if not in detail to this idea (see Szabolcsi and Zwarts 1993, for example).

33 Such facts show that there cannot be an absolute prohibition on certain types of quantifiers (combien ) crossing over others (negation). This would call at the very least for refinements of approaches to these questions, such as Rizzi's (1990b) Relativized Minimality approach.
34 By the Heycock–Kroch proposal mentioned in section 5.3.1, these questions should improve in a context with the right presupposition.
35 Heycock mentions one more example of the same kind. She gives:

subsection.p: (i) *How much faster than John did he see Mary running?
but native speakers rejected even a variant of it without coreference, due to the clash between the tense of the elided VP and its antecedent (running). If the tense clash is resolved as in:
(ii) How much faster than John did does he think Mary ran?
the sentence seems fine. Note also that the underlined part would be barred from reconstructing all the way down, because it would be a paradoxical antecedent-contained deletion structure.
